children.name: for sale
children.definition: if something is for sale, the person who owns it wants to sell it:
examples: để bán
▪ There are several houses for sale in our street.
▪ There was ‘for sale’ notice in the car’s window.
▪ The festival will have food and crafts for sale, games for children, and music.
for sale để bán
available to buy
_Is this painting for sale?
_Our neighboursputtheir houseupfor sale (= started to advertise that they want to sell it) last week.

children.name: on sale
children.definition: if a product is on sale, you can buy it in the shops:
examples: được bán
▪ These cameras are on sale in most electrical stores.go on sale begin to be available
▪ The new model Toyota goes on sale next month.
on saleUK sẵn sàng để bán; có bán
available to buy in a shop
_On sale at record stores now.

children.name: on the market
children.definition: goods that are on the market are available for people to buy -use this especially when you are comparing products of the same general type:

children.name: được bán trên thị trường
examples: ▪ It’s one of the cheapest computers on the market.
▪ There may be better shoes on the market, but this is the one the kids want.

children.name: on the market for
examples: ▪ The house was on the market for $475,000.

children.name: up for sale
children.definition: be   if something such as a house, a shop, or a piece of land is up for sale, it has been publicly announced that it is available for people to buy:

children.name: được rao bán
examples: ▪ The house has been up for sale for months.
▪ Several subsidiary businesses are up for sale.

children.name: when a lot of sth is sold
sell
children.definition: /sel/

children.name: bán được
examples: ▪ Books that don’t sell are sent back to the publishers.
▪ The handcrafted rocking horses have sold well across the United States.
▪ The last model didn’t sell as well as they’d expected.

children.name: best-selling
children.definition: a best-selling product is one that is sold in large numbers, especially more than any other product of the same type:

children.name: bán chạy
examples: ▪ Agatha Christie is said to be the world’s best-selling author.

children.name: ▪ a list of the wegytgek’s best-selling music and children’s videos
examples: ▪ Chanel Number 5 is the best-selling scent of all time.

children.name: best-seller
children.definition: /bestseller/best seller  a book, game, video, record etc that has been bought by a very large number of people:
examples: ▪ Several TV movies have been based on best sellers by Danielle Steel.
▪ Every year there’s a toy that becomes a hard-to-find best-seller.

children.name: bestseller listan official list of what has sold most
examples: ▪ All four Harry Potter books are currently on the bestseller list.

children.name: outsell
children.definition: if one product outsells another, more of it is sold than the other product:
examples: bán chạy hơn
▪ His latest album has outsold all his other records put together.
▪ Chardonnay continues to outsell other wines.
outsellverb[ T ]outsold,outsold stbán chạy hơnst
(of a product) to be sold in greater numbers than another product
_CDs soon began to outsell records.

children.name: be selling like hot cakes
children.definition: if a product is selling like hot cakes, it is being sold very quickly and in large amounts because people very much want to buy it:
examples: ▪ Grisham’s new book is selling like hot cakes.
go/sell like hot cakesinformal
to be bought quickly and in large numbers
_His new video game is apparently selling like hot cakes.

children.name: do a roaring trade
children.definition: if a shop or a person that sells a particular type of goods is doing a roaring trade, they are selling large quantities of goods because a lot of people suddenly want to buy them:
examples: ▪ Since the heatwave started, ice cream vendors have been doing a roaring trade.

children.name: do a roaring trade in
examples: ▪ The shops outside the station were doing a roaring trade in umbrellas.

children.name: sell
children.definition: /sel/  to give something to someone in exchange for money:
examples: ▪ Tom’s thinking of selling his motorcycle and buying a new one.
▪ If you can, wait to sell until prices are high.
▪ Postcards and souvenirs were being sold outside the cathedral.
sell somebody something
▪ The company sold Braugh $100,000 worth of computers at discounted rates.
sell something to somebody
▪ It is illegal to sell tobacco to anyone under the age of 18.
▪ The painting was sold to an art gallery in Philadelphia.
sell something for £250/$50 etc
▪ The antique buttons are very valuable, and we sell them for £100 and upwards.
sellverbsold,soldMONEY bán
[ I or T ] to give something to someone else in return for money
_[ + two objects]I sold him my car/I sold my car to himfor£600.
_We'll be selling the ticketsat/for£50 each.
_The stall sells drinks and snacks.
_These baskets sell well (= a lot of them are bought) .

children.name: export
children.definition: if a country or a company exports its products, it sends them to another country in order to sell them:
examples: ▪ Japanese televisions and hi-fi systems are exported all over the world.
▪ Ancient artefacts cannot be exported.
export something to France/the UK/Japan etc
▪ In 1986 they exported 210,000 cases of wine to the UK.
exporter[countable noun]
▪ Saudi Arabia is one of the world’s leading exporters of oil.
export[adjective only before noun]
▪ Export earnings are lower than last year.
exportverb xuất khẩu
[ I or T ] to send goods to another country for sale
_French cheeses are exportedtomany different countries.
_Our clothes sell so well in this country that we have no need to export.

children.name: sell off
children.definition: to sell something, usually a group of things, at a reduced price in order to get rid of it quickly, because you need the money soon, or because it will not last a long time:
examples: bán hạ giá
sell something off
▪ The bakery usually sells its cakes off at half price just before closing time.
sell off something
▪ After the funeral the house contents were sold off quickly to pay all his debts.
▪ The school district may be forced to close schools and sell off land in order to make much-needed repairs.
sellsthoffphrasal verb[ M ]
to charge a low price for something to encourage people to buy it
_They're selling off last year's stock at half price.

children.name: sell up
children.definition: to sell your house, your business, or other things you ownin order to move to a different place or to do something different:

children.name: bán sạch, bán hết
examples: ▪ Why don’t we sell up and move to Canada? Property is really cheap there!
▪ My parents sold up the farm and went to live in Glasgow.

children.name: serve
children.definition: if someone who works in a shop or a bar serves a customer, they help them to buy or choose the goods that they want:
examples: ▪ There was a line of people in front of me who were all waiting to be served.
▪ Estrada was serving a customer when the fire started.
▪ It is illegal to serve alcoholic drinks to anyone under 18.
[ T ] in a shop, restaurant or hotel, to deal with a customer by taking their order,showing or selling them goods, etc.
_Are you being served, madam?
_That's the restaurant where they refused to serve Giles because he was so rude.

children.name: flog
children.definition: informal to sell something, especially something that is oflow qualityor that has somethingwrongwith it:
examples: ▪ There was a man at the market who was flogging watches for £10 each.

children.name: flog somebody something
examples: ▪ Don’t let him flog you his car -- he’s had endless trouble with it.

children.name: peddle
children.definition: to sell goods, usually things that are cheap, especially by going from place to place rather than selling them in a shop:

children.name: bán rong
examples: ▪ Street vendors peddled flowers and candles.
▪ Belloni started her bakery business by peddling her homemade bread to local stores.

children.name: deal in
children.definition: to buy and sell a particular kind of goods as part of your business:
examples: ▪ The gallery deals mostly in paintings but they do sometimes sell photographs.
▪ Tax agents are visiting more than 5,000 businesses that deal in expensive items such as cars, boats, and jewels.

children.name: flog
children.definition: informalto sell something, especially something that is of low quality or that has something wrong with it:
examples: ▪ There was a man at the market who was flogging watches for £10 each.

children.name: flog somebody something
examples: ▪ Don’t let him flog you his car -- he’s had endless trouble with it.

children.name: peddle
children.definition: to sell goods, usually things that are cheap, especially by going from place to place rather than selling them in a shop:
examples: ▪ Street vendors peddled flowers and candles.
▪ Belloni started her bakery business by peddling her homemade bread to local stores.
peddleverb[ T ]mainly disapproving bán rong; bán rao
to sell things, especially by taking them to different places
_These products are generally peddled (from) door to door.
_He travels around, peddling hiswares.

children.name: trading
children.definition: the activity of selling goods or shares in companies:
examples: ▪ Trading started briskly on the New York Stock Exchange this morning.

children.name: stop/cease trading
examples: ▪ The company ran out of money and was forced to cease trading.

children.name: service
children.definition: nounDEALING WITH CUSTOMER

children.name: when all of sth has been sold
sell out
children.definition: if a shop, ticket office etc sells out ofgoodsortickets, or if goods or tickets sell out, all of them are sold so there are no more available:
examples: được bán hết
▪ I went to the store to get some bread but they had sold out.
▪ Sunday newspapers often sell out by 10 o'clock.
sell out of : bán sạch, bán hết
▪ They opened at 8 o'clock, and by 8.30 they had sold out of tickets for the big game.
be sold outwhen all the tickets for a performance or sports event have been sold
▪ We couldn’t get tickets anywhere - the show was completely sold out.
sell outphrasal verbSELL ALLbán hết
Ifa supply of somethingsells out, there is no more of that thing to buy
_The first issue of the magazine sold out within two days.

children.name: be a sell-out U
children.definition: be a sell-out  if a play, football game, concert etc is a sell-out, it is very popular and all the tickets for it have been sold:
examples: ▪ The band’s European tour was a sell-out.

children.name: sell-out crowd
examples: ▪ The Mariners beat the Angels in front of a sell-out crowd.

children.name: out of stock
children.definition: be   if a product or the shop selling the product is out of stock, the shop does not have any of that product available now, because they have sold all of it:

children.name: hết hàng
examples: ▪ The scooters are popular and are often out of stock.
▪ We’re out of stock, but we can put one on order for you.

children.name: be booked up/fully booked U
children.definition: be booked up/fully booked  if a hotel, restaurant, or organized trip somewhere is booked up or fully booked, all the places have been bought and there are no more available:

children.name: đã được đặt hết
examples: ▪ Flights to the US are all booked up this time of year.
▪ Popular campsites are fully booked on weekends for most of the summer.

children.name: to sell sth to the person who offers the most money
auction
children.definition: alsoauctionoff
examples: bán đấu giá
▪ One of the Beatles’ guitars is being auctioned for charity.
▪ The contents of the house were auctioned to pay off the family’s debts.
auctionverb[ T ] auction something offbán đấu giá
to sell something in a public auction
_The stamps will be auctioned tomorrow.
_The family is auctioning(off)its art collection.

children.name: put sth up for auction
children.definition: put something upfor auction  to arrange for something be sold at a public meeting to the person who offers to pay the most money:

children.name: đưa ra bán đấu giá
examples: ▪ After months trying to sell the farm, they decided to put it up for auction.
▪ One of the world’s finest collections of vintage cars is to be put up for auction.

children.name: come/go under the hammer
children.definition: if something comes or goes under the hammer, especially something valuable such as a famous painting, it is sold at an auction:

children.name: được đưa ra bán đấu giá
examples: ▪ A collection of prints and paintings by Picasso came under the hammer at Sotheby’s yesterday.

children.name: auction
children.definition: a public meeting at which things are sold to the person who offers to pay the most money:
examples: ▪ The buyer did not attend the auction, but sent a representative to place the bids.
hold an auction
▪ Sotheby’s decided to hold auctions in Japan twice a year.
at (an) auction
▪ Bikes that have not been claimed by the owners will be sold at a public auction January 11.
▪ How much do you think the painting would fetch at auction?
auctionnoun[ C or U ] cuộc bán đấu giá
a usually public sale of goods or property, where people make higher and higherbids (= offers of money) for each thing, until the thing is sold to the person who will pay most
_a furniture auction
_They'reholdingan auctionofjewellery on Thursday.
_The painting will be soldat/UK alsobyauction next week.
_The house and its contents are beingput up forauction.

children.name: to make sth available for people to buy
put sth on the market
children.definition: put something on the market alsocome/go on the market

children.name: tung ra thị trường
examples: ▪ We put our house on the market last September and we still haven’t sold it.
▪ The drug came on the market in the late 1990s and has been widely prescribed.
▪ The car will probably sell for around $50,000 when it goes on the market.
▪ Most wines are left to mature before they are put on the market.

children.name: put sth up for sale
children.definition: put something up for sale  to make something such as a house, business, or piece of land available for people to buy:

children.name: đưa ra bán
examples: ▪ The historic property has been put up for sale.
▪ After the merger, parts of the business are likely to be put up for sale.

children.name: bring out
children.definition: if a company brings out a new product that they have made, they make it available for people to buy:
examples: xuất bản, phát hành, tung ra
bring out something
▪ Kodak brought out a camera which stores up to 100 images on a computer disc.
bring something out
▪ The two cookbooks have sold well, and Doubleday is bringing them out in new paperback editions.
bringsthoutphrasal verb[ M ]PRODUCE
to produce something to sell to the public
_They keep bringing out smaller phones.

children.name: launch
children.definition: if a company launches a new product, they publicly announce, especially with a lot of advertising, that it is available for people to buy:

children.name: tung ra , ra mắt
examples: ▪ Fiat launched a tiny ‘city car’ especially for Europe’s narrow, crowded streets.
▪ Fezza, the clothes designer, launched his first collection in 1980.

children.name: release
children.definition: if a company releases arecordorfilm, it makes it available for people to buy or see:
examples: release[countable noun] something that has been released::
▪ The band’s latest release record that has been released▪ should be in the stores Friday.
phim ảnh

children.name: phát hành, tung ra
examples: ▪ Her new album will be released at the end of the month.
▪ Carrey’s new comedy is due to be released in the US very soon.

children.name: publish
children.definition: to print a book, magazine, or newspaper and make it available for people to buy:
examples: publication/ˌpʌblɪˈkeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun] when something is published::
▪ Since the publication of her book, she’s received thousands of letters from women who have had similar experiences.
publisher[countable noun] a company that publishes books::
▪ None of the big UK publishers wanted to do a paperback version of the book.

children.name: xuất bản, phát hành
examples: ▪ Ladybird publish books for young children.
▪ Amateur Photographer is published every Tuesday.
▪ Rowling’s latest Harry Potter novel sold millions of copies as soon as it was published.

children.name: take sth off the market U
children.definition: take something off the market  if a company takes a product off the market, it stops producing it and shops stop selling it:

children.name: rút khỏi thị trường
examples: ▪ The mineral water was taken off the market while tests were being made.
▪ Sales of the newspaper were so poor that it was taken off the market within a couple of months.
▪ The Federal Drug Administration has said that all products containing the additive must be taken off the market immediately.

children.name: withdraw
children.definition: if a shop or a company withdraws a product, it makes it unavailable for people to buy by removing it from shops:
examples: withdrawal[uncountable noun]
▪ Stores have agreed to the withdrawal of the offending videos.

children.name: thu hồi
examples: ▪ Newsagents across the country have withdrawn the magazine after numerous complaints from women’s groups.
▪ After two children had been hurt, the company was forced to withdraw the toy from store shelves.

children.name: withdraw something from sale
examples: ▪ Christmas decorations were withdrawn from sale yesterday following a fire-risk warning.

children.name: recall
children.definition: if acompanyrecalls a product, they ask all the shops that sell it and the people that have bought it to send it back to them for checking, because there may be somethingwrongwith it:
examples: recall/rɪˈkɔːlǁrɪˈkɔːl, ˈriːkɔːl/ [uncountable noun]
▪ They put a notice in the press ordering the recall of all the baby food that might have been contaminated.

children.name: rút lại, thu hồi
examples: ▪ Thousands of car baby-seats have had to be recalled after a fault was discovered in the safety harness.
▪ The company voluntarily recalled about 11,000 of the devices to check them for defects.

children.name: get rid of sth
children.definition: get rid ofsth tống khứ

children.name: to sell an old or unwanted possession
examples: _Have you managed to get rid of your old Volvo yet?

children.name: sale
children.definition: nounSELL sự bán, việc bán

children.name: retail
children.definition: noun (sự)bán lẻ; việc bán lẻ

children.name: the activity of selling goods to the public, usually in small quantities
examples: _The job is open to applicants with over two years' experience in retail.
_The clothing company has six retailoutlets(= shops) in south-easternAustralia.

children.name: the sale of sth
children.definition: the sale of something  when something is sold:
examples: ▪ The rebels are using money from the sale of drugs to buy weapons.
▪ The law prohibits the sale and consumption of alcohol on unlicensed premises.

children.name: telesales/ telemarketing U
children.definition: telesalesnoun (UStelemarketing) bán hàng qua điện thoại
examples: the advertising or selling of goods or servicesby telephone

children.name: retail at/for sth
children.definition: retail at/forsth đượcbán lẻvới giá

children.name: to be soldat a particular price
examples: _This model of computer is retailing at £650.

children.name: salesmanship
children.definition: noun nghệ thuật bán hàng

children.name: skill in selling
examples: _Clever salesmanship can persuade you to buy things you don't really want.

children.name: resell
children.definition: verbresold,resold bán lại (cái gì mình đã mua cho một người khác)

children.name: to sell something which you previously bought
examples: _He buys up run-down properties, fixes them up and resells them.
